The condition of the Active File is less than satisfactory. While a large
majority of the applicants' files are in good order, some are minus from
one to four complete sets of forms and reference statements. These miss¬
ing sets were sent out prior to October 18, 195^ and record of where
and when they were sent has been misplaced. The question of how these
missing sets will be replaced is yet to be determined. With the creation
of new files and the establishment of definite procedures, it is felt that
this problem has been corrected or at least the danger of its repetition
considerably lessened.
Since the arrival of a large file cabinet, the Placement Service has more
than adequate room in which to arrange its files in an orderly fashion.
It shall be the duty of the Placement Officer to check and re—check these
files in order to insure a maximum of efficiency. likewise, the Placement
Officer shall add any new files he deems necessary.
III. THE PLACEMENT OFFICER SHALL DETERMINE WHATEVER PROCEDURES ARE NECESSARY
FOR THE EFFICIENT OPERATION OF THE PLACEMENT SERVICE.
STATEMENT
The purpose of the following procedures is to insure that all necessary
steps are taken in the processing of files and reports and to guard against
the misplacement or inaccurate keeping of records.
The procedures determined at this time are as follows:
A. PROCESS OF APPLICATION FOR ACTIVE FILE STATUS
This procedure is designed to insure that all necessary forms are
sent to the applicant and that their sending is properly recorded.
T he steps taken in this procedure are:
1. Letter of application is received.
2. Folder is assembled and mailed,
a. 5 copies of Forms 1 thro-ugh 7
b. 1 copy of Form 11
c. 1 copy of Form 12
d. 1 copy of Form 13
e. 1 copy of Instruction Sheet
f. 1 copy of General Statement Sheet
3. Applicant is entered on Inactive Mailing List.
4. Application letter is placed in the Inactive File.
